segments.text: The Innovation Department at Yale, since 1992, is well known to many of you.
Preservation microphone frames to digital images.

Prior to Yale, Paul conducted research projects for three years at the National Archives, including a study of research using archives and a review of how government agencies implement digital imaging and optical technology.
During 1988-89,
He served as the Preservation Program Officer of the Office for the Society of American Archivists in Chicago, where he carried out a nationwide survey of archival preservation programs.
He began his professional career as an archivist on the staff of the Gerald Ford Library in Ann Arbor, Michigan.
He has a master's degree and a PhD in information and library studies both from the University of Michigan.
Paul is widely published.
on both preservation and archival management topics.
Most recently, his writing has focused on the challenges of preserving library resources in a digital format.
Paul also wanted me to note to you that his talk will be on the Nellahan website.
And he also has a handout within the packet of websites you can go to.
Thank you.
I have the good fortune of being the only person on the program today who is also with a digital reality one.
So I have the two years ago.
So I have the advantage of the opportunity to connect some dots that wouldn't necessarily be able to be connected otherwise.
A lot has happened in two years.
Digital reality one was only two years ago.
It feels like all of a sudden there's a lot of renewed interest or new interest in preserving a born digital material that is reborn in digital form.
I also have a few other challenges.
One is to keep you awake after lunch.
And the third obligation that I have is, I think, is a mixed obligation.
One is, the simple part is to set up the issues so that the following two speakers have a context within which to build their comments about stimulation and migration.

i think that at a larger level what i'm trying to get at is is kind of get you to walk out of the room and say yes yes this is something i need to think about yes this is something i need to do and yes this is something that is doable by in this particular case the idea that preservation has a role to play in the building
So I'd like to start.
So in essence, my topic is really three parts.
I want to provide the context, talk about the debates on digital preservation and points to some issues.
We'll start with the context of today.
We're living in a digital world.
We know this.
The evidence is everywhere.
But I'd like to give you, at least for starters, the five top reasons I think we're living in the digital world.
Archive has become a verb.
The archivist in me still cringes.
I can't seem to get away from it.
Keyboard's now a number of office workers.
I think it's almost two to one now.
There are more keywords than there are people who do the work.
I read last week in the New York Times that there's now a hyperlink for every man, woman, and child in the face of the earth.
Seven billion plus links.
Nobody carries cash.
And the final reason.
Profit is accepted.
We know we're in a digital world when they have to get money.
Okay.
We also know we're in a digital world because the digital world is changed by a way of thinking about how we relate to each other.
Can you read that?
Go ask your search engine.

Okay, what I'm going to do is lay the context in terms of both time and space for digital preservation to talk about the issues that there seems to be a genuine debate about whether digital preservation is
appropriate or not, whether the work we do is only access.
And in the process of doing so, there are some definitions that I hope will help us through the rest of the day.
And then point out the definition of digital preservation is only one of the issues that we want to look at down the road.
The first question on the table for us is whether digital preservation is real or not, or simply a metaphor.
There's a lot of talk about that, of course.
And I think I hope that I'll convince you that we're actually reading.
OK.
The place to start is way back in time.

This is a chart that I put in a book I published, a report I published in 1996, Preservation of the Digital World, which basically shows the history of recorded media and the relationship between our ability to store information, and the fragility of the media that we're dealing with.
You'll notice all the way there, media in order when they were popular as recording media, starting with playing tablets and moving all the way up
disks and optical disks through Moby Dick, the beginning of the Brittle Books period, and newspapers, Microdillo and Fiche.

The point here is that as our ability to store material compactly has increased from 50, 60, 40, 100 characters per square inch up to the present 51 million disks and holes twice, three times that now.
The life expectancy of these media has declined equivalently.
And we're looking at a 10,000-year life expectancy here.
A lot more trained and recorded history.
For libraries, archives, and museums, of course, we know that we have the challenge of preserving all of these materials in some form.
Not every library has clay tablets, but there are quite a few out there.
Not every library has illuminated manuscripts, but there are quite a few out there.
And everybody has a brittle book or two floating around.
OK, so where we are now is, as the science fiction writer Bruce Sterling has said, we're in this golden age of dead media.
Most of them are working lives.
And that's kind of where we are now from 10,000 years.
Now we can call that progress.
And I think there is a lot to be said for the progress that we've made in terms of being able to develop new media.
But there's an issue here with the media itself.
Now let's look the other direction.
Do you recognize this?
This is Danny Ilse's Millennium Clock that was unveiled on New Year's Day, the year 2000.
It ticks off the air, long slumps a century.
This item is being built.
It's nine feet tall.
I'll back up.
It's nine feet tall, made out of brass and steel.
And it's being built in the deserts of Utah.
A prototype is being built.
is this little item calibrates automatically.
This is the dial.
It's about two feet in diameter.
It calibrates automatically because we can count on the sun coming up and going down forever, at least until it doesn't come up anymore.
And so it automatically calibrates, but it needs to be wound by human beings.
And in Danny Ellis' design for the Millennium Clock, he was determined that this metaphor of maintenance
the metaphor of human beings' involvement with their technology be preserved in even something that was designed to last 10,000 years.
So now we have a 20,000-year time frame.
Now we've been talking about Twinkies, a pack of Twinkies, where we are in terms of being here today.
Now let's go back a little bit further in time.
The point that I want to make in the next couple of slides is that the digital technology as we know it has been around for a very long time.
The idea of phase two, big sixth grade math,

was full blown from the brilliant mind of Godfrey Wilhelm von Leibniz, who invented the idea of base two and conceived of a mathematical system in which all very life's experience could be coded in ones and zeros some 350 years ago.
And he designed a machine that wasn't built for another 200 years, but the prototype for it was in his notebooks.
for a calculating machine that was based on base two, way before Charles Babbage was born, much less designed his calculating machine, his differential engine.
The other piece of the digital technology that's been around a long time is the idea that what digital is all about is communication, sending information from one space to another.
Now, we've had two centers this morning who've made this point as well.
It's not about the media.
It's not necessarily about necessarily conversion of something.
It's about how we work and live together.

of about a fifth copy of image of what was called the visual telegraph that ran from London to the old 200 years ago, in which a six or seven foot high platform, a person stood on top of that platform and looked to the horizon and waited for the six disks to change pattern.
And when this person saw those disks turn from black to white, he or she replicated, it's probably a he.
turned the blacks from blacks to white.
And a person looking on the horizon in the other direction watched for that to change.
And it was possible to send a digital signal from one coast to another in a matter of 40 or 50 seconds once you got trained.
But of course, there was a tremendous administrative overhead to this kind of thing.
The point here is that we've been concerned as humans about efficient communication and coded communication for a very, very long time.
And even the infrastructure of networks and input-output streams and storage media and digital communication has been a part of our life, many parts of our lives, since World War II.
So this is not a brave new world necessarily.
We have a tremendous amount of stability in the midst of change.
As I've mentioned, we've got digital mathematics theory that's been around for 350 years.
It gives us the tools to do what Tim Berners-Lee described.
He talked about coding the world in mathematical forms.
We're there.
The basic technology infrastructure is solid and well supported.
But what's changing so rapidly, the feeling of a revolution is how we actually use this technology in our lives.
In Wired Magazine a couple years ago, Steve Steinberg wrote an essay about what's changed and what's happened in the last five years with digital technologies.
And his conclusion, which he was wistful and regretful about, was that nothing much has happened.
and felt that that was a cause for concern.
But for those of us in libraries, archives, and museums, some sense of stability in this technology is a cause for optimism.
And I think that Tim and others, even Walt, were talking about, we can count on certain things.
Now, three years ago, we couldn't make that conversation.
We were all worried about the ephemera of digital technology, but we have a certain room for optimism here now.
okay now i need to begin looking ahead with preservation in some senses is about prediction and about lowering our risk george gilder who

walt mentioned this morning uh we i could describe who george gilter is and i won't i won't do that but he he did write a nice essay in last week's new yorker or that he was described in last week's new york new yorker as being critical of most projectors most most prognosticators as being focused on catastrophe anybody that looks forward tends to see the worst and what the doomsmeers don't understand is that is that the reason humans revels creativity
where that creativity always comes as a surprise.
Now, we know that the World Wide Web has come over us as a surprise, even though it took 10, 15 years
to think about it, figure it out, convince many people that he wasn't crazy, and build a base for a revolution that comes to us as a surprise.
And I think that as we're looking forward to digital preservation, we have to remember that we're constantly surprising ourselves with our ability to deal with complicated issues.
The second point, which should be obvious after half a morning of talking about this, is that the web is not a library.
The web is not a library because the information is not all there, and I think we clarified that this morning.
It's lacking standards and validation to name two of the things that are wrong with the World Wide Web.
And there's minimal cataloging.
We know that for a fact, or any kind of descriptive standards.
And retrieval is still, for now, ineffective.
I mean, with Google up there, only through Wall's web page is number one.
It's still not quite there.
And so my contention is that preservation is the job for libraries.
And it's the job for archives, the job for museums.
It's the job for organizations whose mission is to keep them for the good of somebody, the organization itself, or their reader, or their users, or society.
And so we have a special job with preservation, and that job has always been a part of libraries.
And Tim confirmed that this morning.
He said, I'm hoping that you librarians out there will tell us all what to do.
And I put a smile on my face.
I don't know about you when he said that, because that's a validating power over what we have to do, which is figure out how to do this preservation thing.
OK.
So the question is, what's the place of preservation theory and practice in a world dominated by information created in the digital world?
Big deal here.
And the risk here is unbelievable investment.
Anybody who's doing any budget work for your libraries, archives, or museums now know what the toll is for digital resources right now.
There's still a pretty high risk loss.
We haven't yet had, I'm waiting for the Florence plug.
of the digital world.
If you know anything about conservation, the Florence flood galvanized the conservation community to deal effectively with catastrophe among resources.
We haven't had a Florence flood yet.
And this world of constant product development, which makes us feel like we're in the midst of a chaotic world.
Instead, what we're looking at is not the World Wide Web as something to preserve, but as digital libraries as something to build.
And I'm using the word library broadly as an organization.
This is Don Waters' definition.
This sounds a lot like the definition of a regular library with a couple of exceptions.
It's an organization that has resources, including specialized assets, does all these things, select, structure, offer intellectual access, interpret,
resources, distribute, preserve the integrity of collections for digital works so that they're readily available and economically available for use by a defined community.
Defined, it suggests choices we make about what our audience is.
So what we're really looking at is building a product, and that's my point of departure for digital preservation.
OK.
Now, I probably have convinced you already.
Oh, this is logical.
Of course.
That's what I'm here to do, is to make you say yes.
But there's a debate out there.
And what's that debate going on here?
Maybe this is professional jealousy or something.
Some people have had a few grandchildren.
associated with digital preservation.
And I want to tell you about a few of that in a few minutes here.
First, some precedence.
The idea of digital preservation, I think, has largely emerged not out of the library preservation community, but out of the archives community.
Anybody who's thought or worried or taken a workshop in the 1980s about the problem of electronic records immediately understands what the basic problem is of digital material.

And in the pre-1980s and up through the 1980s, there was a lot of work going on, a lot of angst, mostly, in the archives community about electronic records, which then became codified as a research agenda, prompted by people like Margaret Hedstrom, who's now at the University of Michigan, and then originally she was at the New York State Archives Program.
Richard Cox, way preceding many of us, and thinking constructively about this, the National Archives,
working off and on, in and out, all around the bush to get focused.
Contracted with a number of people to do studies, including the National Association of Public Administrators, a major study for the National Archives.
But it was pretty much under the light, was under the bushel until the ROG Commission on Preservation and Access Task Force on Archiving.
The digital record came along in 1996, chaired by Don Waters,
And John Garrett, who put a report together.
It's listed in your handout.
It's on the web.
It'll be .
And it clarified, it defined for us this idea of migration.
It gave a vow to emulation without really giving it much due.

And it focused on the need to focus on born digital materials primarily, perhaps at the expense of, in a limited world of limited resources, reborn digital, which I'm thinking of as all the stuff that we're sitting on in our institutions now.

conversion of legacy collections into digital form and if tim you know we he we went back and forth over the grave whether he says anything important is going to be on the web maybe that's true in terms of managing our organizations but it's not true in terms of scholarship communication learning teaching and all the things that are bread and butter there's still a lot of work to do my focus when i
I had the good fortune of reading a draft of the RLG CPA Task Force and realized that the reborn digital piece wasn't being discussed.
I had the opportunity to write the preservation in the digital world, which I'm going to summarize in the next.
And now we're seeing, all of a sudden, what I'm calling, you know, what we could think of is the new cottage industry on digital preservation.
Everywhere you turn in the world of higher education, you have people, task forces groups, some talking to each other and some not, worrying about what we're going to do about digital preservation.
And I think this is a wonderful thing, in fact, that we've got a high level of anxiety happening.
Now, I had a 20,000-year time frame.

preservation 10 000 in the past and 10 000 in the future here we have four orders of magnitude less 10 10 years we've had a tremendous amount of progress we should pat ourselves on that that we that the idea that we might want to have a preservation sensibility built into this digital arena was a new idea 10 years ago and it's virtually a clear concept now we can't do it yet but it's a clear concept
We have a tremendous amount of research and development, both nationally and internationally, in all kinds of arenas, shared and unshared results.
Best practices emerging for most kinds of materials.
We know how to do text.
We are pretty close to knowing how to do black and white photographs.
We're getting there on color.
We're getting there on oversized materials.
We're not there on newspapers, yada, yada.
There's a lot of people working on how to create digital resources.
There's a tremendous amount of work going on, at least in the last couple years, on information architectures, which is all the underlying database structures that help ties all together.
It's the nodes on the internet, and what happens when you land on one of those?
What do you get?
The architectures for these digital libraries are emerging with amazing speed in the last couple of years.
Models for transformative digital products, we have wonderful resources out there that we can point to as successes so far.
Ones that look like they will persist, JSTOR.
the documenting the American Self Project at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, LC's American Memory Program.
Not all of it is your tax dollars at work either.
A lot of it is your former vacancy that went away to pay for a digital product.
national leadership in the infrastructure.
We have a voice.
It's in the Council on Library and Information Resources and it's in the National Digital Library Federation voice.
Now how effective that voice is and how stable that voice is is my next slide.
The Council on Library and Information Resources is a co-joining of the old Council on Library Resources and the Commission on Reservation and Access.
It became an entity in 1987, I believe, and has been a vocal advocate for preservation, both traditionally and in digital forms.
But the message is morphing on us, and that's what I want to show you here.
In 1997, the annual report for the first annual report for CLEAR said the digital surrogates are for access only.
followed up by a report that said digitization addresses no serious preservation issues.
And I am quoting out of context.
And if Don and Waters and Abby Smith and Deanna Markham were sitting here, we would be having a dialogue.
Don Waters was the one that quality is a metaphor, which I then turned around three weeks later and put that slide up that says, you know, the good news follows it.
The doctor says it's only a metaphor.
Permanence and authenticity are a good length.
The focus on that line is that you can't possibly have preservation because the media isn't permanent and you can sneak in in the dead of night and change that digital file.
I could remove myself from this presentation if I wanted to.
But we have a new director of the Digital Library Federation, Dan Greenstein.
who didn't come out of the United States world of digital politics, but came out of the English world of digital politics, which is probably no better or no worse than the American one.
But he has a different perspective.
He said the digital preservation thing is something we have to do, and the whole, it's so complex, but let's start close to home.
Let's start with trying to preserve our own assets, the ones we created.
Let's begin with preserving digital surrogates that we have created.
And so in the course of only three years, we've gone full circle.
And that's only three years.
So, I'm back to... What is preservation?
No, the manual is 99.
I first hatched this idea in 96 and it became fully fleshed out in the latest edition of the NEDCC preservation manual.
Preservation is the creation of digital products worth maintaining over time.
And if you remember something from my presentation, take that sentence away, because it's loaded with assumptions, and it's loaded with requirements.
It's not a metaphor.
It's something we do.
It's is.
It's not is-like.
The creation, all of a sudden, libraries, archives, and museums, we know this, but we have to face up to the fact that we're in the product creation business.
Product creation business.
Digital products worth maintaining over time.
Value, if we don't add value,
then we're not creating something worth maintaining over time.
I'll mention, I'll go on a little bit about this in a minute, but the point here is that this creates a fairly high bar for us.
That we're not simply copying material into another medium and calling it done and walking right away.
We have to first transform our perspective on preservation in order to tackle the digital preservation issues.
Our way of looking at traditional preservation must change from
From locally to collaboration, so much of what we do is based on what's good for General Motors and Yale is good for General Motors and Yale, and the rest of us can follow.
From standards to best practices and back again, and I rushed at lunch.
I rushed upstairs and put the NBAC again in there in response to Tim Berners-Lee's comments about the place of standards.

Those of us in the preservation and library and archives community have tended to walk away from standards because of the cumbersome standards process that takes 10 to 15 years to get something, a meta-standard, some big thing that's 400 page thick standards, whether it's archives records management in Australia or whatever, it's an impossible process.
And we said the best that we can do is consensus on the way to do the job, which is what best practice is.
What Tim has reminded us is that underneath that best practice are some basic things that we need to agree that we have to call standards.
We wouldn't have the world wide world if there wasn't.
Some minimal level of standardization is really what it's all about.
So it's this combination of perhaps abandoning the broad-based standards process.
It's not abandoning it, at least putting it on the backseat, emphasizing best practices for getting the job done, but recognizing that those best practices won't be best
unless there's an underlying technology standard that backs them up.
It's open systems standards, open software, etc.
From product to product, I've belabored this one already.
Most of our traditional preservation work has been fairly linear.
We're looking at something more complex now.
And we have rescued ownership.
The preservation ethic embedded in the copyright laws of the United States and other countries allows preservation of anything.
even whether it's owned by copyright or not, in the interest of preservation.
But we now know with the Digital Millennium Copyright Act that we can preserve something, but we can't make it available because we don't own it.
For moral right to business plan, preservation was built on the fact that it was the right thing to do.
But we're in an environment where business plans are going to make a difference, and so we have to have that.
The product itself has to be transformed.
Thinking of what we are doing with creating a digital product has to change.
And what we've got is a set of relationships that starts with the reason we're doing this in the first place.
Are we just trying to protect our materials from further damage by putting them online and putting the derivatives online?
Are we trying to facilitate research interpretation by representing the information in those sources?
Or, as I would suggest we really need to focus on, create applications that take maximum advantage by the technology itself, transcendent,
applications that transform our way of doing business, that transform our way of learning and teaching.
Once you've got that one down, then you worry about what stuff you're going to convert to.
We've had some conversations about selection and choice.
We tend to look first at content and then form and format genre, then the structure and how we put that together.
All the pieces relate to each other and then what we're representing in digital form.
If I had more time, the whole issue of representation in digital form is worth a 45-minute talk in itself, this transformative process in what we actually do.
For instance, when you digitize a photograph, do you leave the border of the photograph on or off?
Do you enhance the photograph?
If it's a glass plate negative, do you take the crack out?
We'll leave it in.
This sounds like trivia, but it has to do with what we're trying to tell ourselves and others when we do our digital representation.
There are tremendously complicated issues about representation in digital form that we have to work on collectively.
But they go for these transcendent applications.
And then finally, and only finally, do we get to the technology capabilities.
All too often, the process goes in the other direction.
We start with technology, sometimes because we're given a gift of technology, and say, okay, now what are we going to do?
And then we sit down and say, what could we digitize and get on the web?
And then you're already two years into the process, and you say, why are we doing this anyway?
These relationships define quality and cost, and that they also influence selection, integrity, accessibility, which are the issues that I think that we're dealing with in preservation.
Five basic core preservation factors have to inform the creation of our digital products.
Concern about longevity.
It's not about media, but it is about media.
You have to store it someplace, in some file format, somewhere.
So digital technology, in essence, is not media.
But it is about media.
And longevity storage systems are a major issue.
Quality, which we've been focusing on for 10 years almost exclusively, is on image and text data quality.
Fortunately, now our attention has shifted away from fretting over quality, because we can do it, to a concern for how we're going to describe this material in digital form.
selection is always out there, and accessibility, or consistent functionality.
And that's my setup for, this is the beginning of my setup for the next two talks.
Okay.
We're going to have two talks this afternoon.
Let me go back one step.
You'll notice that there are five core values that have to inform the building of our digital products.
Longevity, quality, integrity, selection, and accessibility.
What we're going to be hearing about this afternoon is largely about accessibility.
And I think that that's an issue that we're going to want to look at.
The other four are temporarily off the table.
We have two alternative scenarios.
Finette Eaton is going to talk about migration, and Jeff Rothenberg is going to talk about emulation.
So I thought I'd provide a basic definition for each, and then move on to a bunch of issues that I think we have to think about.
OK, this is from the Waters and Garrett Report from 1996, which is available online.
Migration is a set of organized tasks, periodic transfer of digital materials, cross-target software platforms,
and across technology generations and or across generations.
It's prediction.
Full functionality of the original object may or may not be preserved in this process.
Emulation uses its software.
It's to build a software package that deeply describes the software package that includes both the hardware, the capabilities of the hardware as well as the software and all the data.
therein.
Longevity is conferred, then, because you've made the issue of obsolescence go away.
The original functionality and content are fixed.
At least this is my understanding of that.
I think Jeff might have something to say about that.
OK, emulation, there's some pros and cons.
I mean, there's some issues.
Emulation tends to be a once and for all.
Do it once and be done with it, which sounds kind of like preservation.
With migration, there's periodic intervention, five years, seven years, 10 years, 15 years, when emulation fixes functions more or less in time.
If you decide to emulate a WordStar 1.0 running on a leading edge computer with a 286 Intel chip inside of it, you fix WordStar 1.0.
All the data that was created on WordStar 1.0, particularly picking an easy mark,
What about the 1980 census that we want to emulate how the census is organized?
So that in 300 years, we can read the 1980 census in all of its glory in electronic form.
That's a harder mark.
That's not so easy to shoot at.
And emulation data tends to be fixed.
There's a great potential that as you migrate, you lose something.
There's a real possibility.
Emulation emphasizes certainty.
We want certainty.
We want to sleep at night.
We don't know what we're doing right now.
Migration is a crack shoot.
We don't know whether it's going to work.
Emulation is independent of value and use.
You don't have to care about what you're emulating because you're just doing it.
Migration, because we can't save everything all the time forever, is completely dependent upon value and use.
So my question, my first issue, my first question is, is technology the carbon source?
Which is it?
Does technology follow from what we want to do with our organizations?
Or is it the driving force that helps us figure out what we're going to do with our organizations?
Not in India.
Okay, now we're on to some more issues.
Okay, so this is a dog egg, making a hole.
So I dig a hole, put the bone in the hole.
What's my motivation for burying them?
You can't bury them.
Dogs just bury bones because they're programmed to bury bones.
They don't need motivation, but we do.
We need motivation.
Okay, I've got a series of little quotes here, but I need my children in order to complete this.
David Levy was at Xerox Park for the longest time.
He's not there anymore, but he's got his own company doing consulting.
But David Levy wrote a classic article that I think is classic, that I quoted in the Blue Bibliography, in which he
He critiques a kind of techno-centric approach to our concern for preservation.
It's that we become so fixed on the artifacts that we've lost sight of their users and their use.
Items that are digital collections that are not used probably will not persist.
It's an important issue to keep in mind as you go forward.
There's a political statement here.
The idea that unused materials will not survive.

implies, it challenges the foundation of a research library or a research archive that's in the business of collecting materials so that one of these days they hope they'll be used or they will be used or they're discovered by another generation of scholars way down the road.
So we could fixate on that mission challenging statement or we could just get over it and get on with measuring use.
We've shied away from systems, building systems that track users in use.
There's a confidentiality issue.
There's a lot of things about use.
And then there's the issue of the quality of use and the quantity of use.
It's easy to count.
It's not so easy to measure.
Does use make a difference?
Are people writing their seminal articles?
Are they getting through sixth grade as a result of having the American memory learning page there in front of them?
So significant use is not necessarily a value judgment.
It doesn't emphasize Ph.D.
research over sixth grade term papers.
It just says, can we understand the fact that there is sixth grade term papers out there and Ph.D.
programs as well, or is it just eight counts through a website?
But my assertion is that at least where we stand now, with the shape of digital standards, with the shape of understanding what we do and how we do it, we have to build a product that will be used.
Because if they aren't, we can't justify their existence.
And that's a tough one.
That's a tough message, I think, and you may too disagree in the end, but I haven't understood the alternative myself.
Okay, the second thing is that certainty is a continuum.
The longer we go out, let's think a hundred years out, and the latest thinking on digital presentations is let's build systems with a hundred year time frame.
And the interesting take on this is the idea that
Preservation used to be into what I used to think of as generational handoff.
I administer a collection and do the best I can and hand it on to my successors, more or less at the point of my retirement.
In other words, generational change.
What we're trying to do is the best we could within a 30, 40, 50 year time frame and then hand it off for our successors who we have trained to come in behind us.
and pick up where we at.
It's a generational handle.
Now the word generation means a five-year computer.
Generation migration, when we talk about multiple generations, we're talking about five years.
If I'm around to see it, that means I have to migrate four or five or six or seven or eight times.
The point of this slide is that we can't necessarily be completely logical about this.

Migration is one of those terms that conveys several meanings.

Margaret Hedstrom and Sheila Montgomery in their December 1998 report, Digital Preservation Needs and Requirements and RLG member institutions, defined migration as the periodic transfer of digital materials
from one hardware or software configuration to another, or from one generation of computer technology to a subsequent generation.

Preserving digital information, report of the Task Force on Archiving Digital Information, which Paul just talked about, defined migration as ensuring that present and future users can retrieve, display, and otherwise use electronic materials
in the face of constantly changing technology.

Terrell Stoller, in his new book, Authentic Electronic Records, Strategies for Long-Term Access, narrows the definition by focusing on the issue that these records come from legacy information systems that lack export software functionality, which currently requires writing special purpose code or programs.
I would like to mention one additional term, conversion.

Charles Beller characterizes conversion as the automatically exporting or importing records from one software environment to another with little or no loss in structure and no loss in content or context, even though the underlying bit stream is altered.

was to re-engineer this process by developing an in-house capability for making preservation copies of electronic files sent to the center by agencies.

We copied about 200 files a year once the center began its accelerated accessioning program.

The staff developed a statement of work that defined the basic requirements and outlined additional features that would improve the process or the life of the contract.
Although in the statement of work we defined what the processes should be, we did not define how they should be accomplished.
There were four objectives with this contract.
First, NARA wanted to retain control of the media and perform the work in-house.
streamlining and saving valuable time and therefore increasing productivity.

On January 6, 1993, two weeks before Bush formally left office, the court ruled that some materials on the White House computer system were federal records and presidential records.

And the courts directed the government, specifically the archivist of the United States, to take all necessary steps to preserve without erasure all electronic federal records generated by the White House agencies.
The archives took physical custody of all the tapes from the White House as the Bush administration was leaving and the Clinton administration took office.

In late May, the court ruled that the archives had not complied with this order to preserve the tapes, found the archives in a state of civil contempt, and levied fines which would amount to $2.5 million if the archives did not come into compliance within 30 days.

upon appeal, it was apparent that the threat of fines and possible imprisonment was very real.

For the third part of my presentation, I would like to focus on three current research projects that are attempting to address issues of interest to the audience.

The first project is a major international research initiative in which archival scholars, computer engineering researchers, national archival institutions, and private industry representatives collaborate to develop theoretical and methodological knowledge
Required for the Permanent Preservation of Authentic Records in Electronic Systems.

Interpari's International Research on Permanent Authentic Records in Electronic Systems, and if you know that, among equals, who spent about three hours working on this name, is seeking to formulate model policies, strategies, and standards that will ensure the permanent preservation of records generated electronically.

I am a member of the US team, which is funded by the National Historical Publications and Records Commission, which is examining the issues relating to both the short and long-term durability, accessibility, and usability of electronic record systems, as well as the authentication of their content.
The US team is also interdisciplinary, drawing remarkable triumphs, preservation management, library and information science,
computer science, and electrical engineering.
And we are working together to identify and model the form, function, and structure of digital systems, their content, and their metadata.
The broad goal of the Interpares project is to develop the theoretical and methodological knowledge essential for the permanent preservation of records created electronically.
And on the basis of this knowledge,
to formulate model policies, strategies, and standards capable of ensuring their preservation based on the requirements of various communities involved in this work.

One focus of the American team is on systems design implications by translating the theoretical model, templates, and typologies into system design requirements and data and metadata models, and then implementing and evaluating those designs and models
from different organizational, social, and national domains and across different types of digital records.
The research plan for this international project has been divided into four interrelated domains of investigation, which are being conducted by passports.
The first domain focuses on the conceptual requirement for preserving authentic records by identifying the elements of electronic records
which are necessary to maintain the authenticity of records over time.

The second domain addresses appraisal criteria, and its goal was determined whether the evaluation of electronic records for permanent preservation should be based on theoretical criteria different from those applied to traditional records.
This task group will also investigate how digital technologies have affected the methodology of appraisal.

The third domain, preservation, is attempting to identify and develop the procedures and resources required for the implementation of the conceptual requirements and criteria identified in the first two domains.
The fourth domain is targeting the formulation of principles that will guide the development of international, national, and organizational strategies, policy, and standards
with a long-term preservation of electronic records based upon the environment in which each institution is located.
Again, looking for best practices.
One of the most important aspects of this research is the wide range of record types that are being tested.
Members of the American team are focusing on electronic record collections from government and universities, which will include student registration systems and collection information systems.
Other countries are looking at automated patent systems, permit systems, and registers of wills.

The work performed by the American team will provide approval concept rule for the enterprise, providing feedback which will then be used to reinforce or modify the theoretical model and generate and test systems analysis and design tools and strategies that can be factored in to future systems design
as well as policy and standard development in the areas of records.

The second research project, funded by the National Archives and Records Administration, in conjunction with the National Science Foundation, is being conducted by the San Diego Supercomputer Center.
Entitled Collection-Based Persistent Digital Archives, the project seeks to bring together and integrate archival storage technology from supercomputer centers.

data grid technology from the computer science community, information models from the digital library community, and preservation models from the archival community to test the feasibility of preserving digital information for long periods of time.

The supercomputer centers provide the technology required to store immense amounts of digital data currently being created, and the digital library community provides mechanisms to define the context needed to interpret the data.

This project defines the challenge as maintaining the ability to discover, access, and display digital objects that are stored within an archive while the technology used to manage the archive evolves.

In this project, they attempt to store digital objects in collections and capture the metadata attributes needed to dynamically recreate the data collection, thus ensuring the migration of the context of these records.

the researchers discuss the project and provide a specific example of how to create a persistent collection of one million email messages.

Support for ingestion, or what I believe most authors would probably call accessioning, archival storage, information discovery, and the presentation of the collection.

The authors describe the creation of a one million message persistent archive collection.
They characterize this persistent archive as two phases.
Remember, these are technologists when I use the next term.
The archiving of the collection and the retrieval or instantiation of the collection onto new technology.
The processes used to adjust the collection
transform it into an infrastructure-independent form using XML and store the information in an archive are the persistent storage steps of this persistent archive.
Processes used to recreate the collection on new technology, optimize the database, and recreate the user interface are the retrieval or migration steps of this persistent archive.

The technology to support each of these processes is still rapidly evolving, and further research is required.

A third initiative, which informs the two projects I just discussed and which I think a lot of you are probably familiar with, is the open archival information system, OASIS, which is an initiative by the National Aeronautics Space Agency's consultative committee for space data systems.
OASIS serves as a conceptual framework for an archival system dedicated to preserving and maintaining access over time.

committee developed this model to increase awareness and understanding of the concepts required preserving digital objects particularly with non-archival institutions elucidate terminology and concepts for describing and comparing data models and archival architectures expand consensus on the elements and processes necessary for digital information preservation and divide a framework

An open archival information system is understood to me, any organization or system that has the task of preserving information over time and making it accessible to a specified class of users, known as the designated community.

are developed in open form.

The OASIS initiative is moving forward with efforts to explore possible areas for standardization within the framework of the reference model.

A workshop in College Park, Maryland in October 1999, Archival Workshop on Ingest, Identification, and Certification Standards, established an initial agenda for pursuing standardization in the areas of ingest, interaction between the archive and the data producer,

Identification, establishing a system of permanent, unique identifiers for archival digital objects, and certification, development of accreditation policies protocols to establish the authenticity, quality, and usefulness of an archive holding.
The workshop also sought to determine who would be interested in participating in working groups dedicated to pursuing standardization in the areas discussed in the workshop.
Response was positive and the groups are expected to form and begin meeting in the near future.

For additional information about this initiative, including the OACIS reference model, proceedings from the workshop, and other material related to the preservation of digital materials, you should visit the site that's on the frame that you have in front of you.
